pullRequest.body:
We add `Commute.orderOf_mul_pow_eq_lcm`: if two commuting elements `x` and `y` of a monoid have order `n` and `m`, there is an element of order `lcm n m`. The result actually gives an explicit (computable) element, written as the product of a power of `x` and a power of `y`.

Co-authored-by: Junyan Xu <[junyanxu.math@gmail.com](mailto:junyanxu.math@gmail.com)>

---

nodes.body: Note that I put the result in `Mathlib.GroupTheory.Exponent` rather than in `Mathlib.GroupTheory.OrderOfElement` to not changing imports too much.

I think @alreadydone is the best way of handling this, using `orderOf_pow_orderOf_div` the proof becomes very reasonable.

I have to stop now, but thanks all for the suggestions!

> Isn't `factorization_lcm_right a b` just `factorization_lcm_left b a`?

I don't think so: there is a difference when the same power of `p` divides both `a` and `b` exactly, in which case it shows up in only one of them (otherwise you could not get two coprime factors whose product is the lcm).

> Isn't `factorization_lcm_right a b` just `factorization_lcm_left b a`? If so, I'm not sure it's worth having the two functions -- and half the lemmas can go, as they are straightforward consequences of the symmetric version.

Almost, but not really: `factorization_lcm_left 2 2 = 2`, but `factorization_lcm_right 2 2 = 1`. The only difference is for prime that appears with the same exponent, we put them in `factorization_lcm_left 2 2` (this is arbitrary of course, but they have to go somewhere).
You're right, sorry. Maybe add a comment about that in one of the definitions?

Thanks!

Isn't `factorization_lcm_right a b` just `factorization_lcm_left b a`? If so, I'm not sure it's worth having the two functions -- and half the lemmas can go, as they are straightforward consequences of the symmetric version.

bors d+
Thanks!

```suggestion (hy : orderOf y ≠ 0) : ```
`kᵢ = pᵢ` doesn't sound right, `pᵢ` is the prime
Of course it's wrong, thanks.
I think this line should be indented a bit more
Shouldn't conclusions say `0 < ..`?
Good idea.
Would it be easier or harder to use this if you made the element a `def`?

I think it would be more or less the same. I can of course extract all the various properties I need, but the proof is ugly just because it concerns stuff like `n / (gcd (n/a) a)`, and `n` and `a` both depend on `x` and `y`, so the need to use  `nth-rewrite` a lot.

I would also put this into [Mathlib/Data/Nat/Factorization/Basic.lean](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/11235/files#diff-5a35c7fed7b39fd34329e2d6cea2700838ca70eb25ce505a38c289e0b093a94d) (unless it needs some import that is missing there) since it is a relevant property of `factorization_lcm_left` and `factorization_lcm_right` and not specific to group exponents.
Ah yes, I forgot to mention it: it needs new imports. But I realize that `Factorization.Basic` already has pretty heavy imports, maybe it's not really a problem. Let me try.
I've moved it, adding the import. I think it is ok.

`hx` and `hy` should not be necessary (take `x` if it has infinite order, similarly for `y`), but the statement would be messy. Perhaps add a version without the nonzero assumptions that just gives the existence statement?
Done.

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
variable (a b)

lemma factorization_lcm_left_dvd : factorization_lcm_left a b ∣ a := by
  rcases eq_or_ne a 0 with rfl | ha
  · simp only [dvd_zero]
  rcases eq_or_ne b 0 with rfl | hb
  · simp [factorization_lcm_left]
```

```suggestion
lemma factorization_lcm_right_dvd : factorization_lcm_right a b ∣ b := by
  rcases eq_or_ne a 0 with rfl | ha
  · simp [factorization_lcm_right]
  rcases eq_or_ne b 0 with rfl | hb
  · simp only [dvd_zero]
```

Add
```suggestion

lemma div_gcd_mul_div_gcd_eq_lcm (a b : ℕ) :
    a / a.gcd (a / factorization_lcm_left a b) * (b / b.gcd (b / factorization_lcm_right a b)) =
      lcm a b := by
  rcases eq_or_ne a 0 with rfl | ha
  · simp only [Nat.zero_div, gcd_self, Nat.div_zero, zero_mul, lcm_zero_left]
  rcases eq_or_ne b 0 with rfl | hb
  · simp only [Nat.zero_div, gcd_self, Nat.div_zero, mul_zero, lcm_zero_right]
  have h₁ := factorization_lcm_left_pos a b
  have h₂ := factorization_lcm_right_pos a b
  obtain ⟨ka, hka⟩ := factorization_lcm_left_dvd a b
  obtain ⟨kb, hkb⟩ := factorization_lcm_right_dvd a b
  have hka' : ka ∣ a := ⟨factorization_lcm_left a b, mul_comm ka _ ▸ hka⟩
  have hkb' : kb ∣ b := ⟨factorization_lcm_right a b, mul_comm kb _ ▸ hkb⟩
  have hka₀ : 0 < ka := Nat.pos_of_ne_zero fun H ↦ ha <| Nat.zero_dvd.mp <| H ▸ hka'
  have hkb₀ : 0 < kb := Nat.pos_of_ne_zero fun H ↦ hb <| Nat.zero_dvd.mp <| H ▸ hkb'
  rw [Nat.div_eq_of_eq_mul_right h₁ hka, Nat.div_eq_of_eq_mul_right h₂ hkb,
    gcd_eq_right_iff_dvd.mp hka', gcd_eq_right_iff_dvd.mp hkb',
    Nat.div_eq_of_eq_mul_left hka₀ hka, Nat.div_eq_of_eq_mul_left hkb₀ hkb]
  exact factorization_lcm_left_mul_factorization_lcm_right ha hb
```
and use that below.
(And similarly for the coprimality statement.)

Maybe define abbreviations for `div_gcd_mul_div_gcd_eq_lcm` and `b / b.gcd (b / factorization_lcm_right a b)`?
Are these actually the same as `facotization_lcm_right b a` and `factorization_lcm_left b a`?
If so, it may be simpler to just use these later (and prove the relevant relations here).

> Add
> 
> and use that below.

This is surely a general lemma unrelated to `factorization_lcm_left` and `factorization_lcm_right`, let me see.

Golf:
```
variable {G}
lemma orderOf_pow_of_dvd {x : G} {n : ℕ} (hn : n ≠ 0) (dvd : n ∣ orderOf x) :
    orderOf (x ^ n) = orderOf x / n := by rw [orderOf_pow' _ hn, Nat.gcd_eq_right dvd]

lemma orderOf_pow_orderOf_div {x : G} {n : ℕ} (hx : orderOf x ≠ 0) (hn : n ∣ orderOf x) :
    orderOf (x ^ (orderOf x / n)) = n := by
  rw [orderOf_pow_of_dvd _ (Nat.div_dvd_of_dvd hn), Nat.div_div_self hn hx]
  rw [← Nat.div_mul_cancel hn] at hx; exact left_ne_zero_of_mul hx
/- above: move to OrderOfElement -/

open Nat in
lemma _root_.Commute.orderOf_mul_pow_eq_lcm {x y : G} (h : Commute x y) (hx : orderOf x ≠ 0)
    (hy : orderOf y ≠ 0) :
    orderOf (x ^ (orderOf x / (factorization_lcm_left (orderOf x) (orderOf y))) *
      y ^ (orderOf y / factorization_lcm_right (orderOf x) (orderOf y))) =
      Nat.lcm (orderOf x) (orderOf y) := by
  rw [(h.pow_pow _ _).orderOf_mul_eq_mul_orderOf_of_coprime]
  all_goals iterate 2 rw [orderOf_pow_orderOf_div]; try rw [Coprime] /- necessary because `simp` unfolds Coprime, which is reducible -/
  all_goals simp [factorization_lcm_left_mul_factorization_lcm_right, factorization_lcm_left_dvd,
    factorization_lcm_right_dvd, coprime_factorization_lcm_left_factorization_lcm_right, hx, hy]
```

We shouldn't need this as it's a simple combination of existing lemmas:
```suggestion
  rw [Nat.gcd_eq_right (Nat.div_dvd_of_dvd hx), Nat.gcd_eq_right (Nat.div_dvd_of_dvd hy),
    Nat.div_div_self hx ha, Nat.div_div_self hy hb]
```
Mmm, maybe you're right.

```suggestion
`kᵢ = mᵢ` if `mᵢ ≤ nᵢ` and `0` otherwise. -/
```

```suggestion
`kᵢ = nᵢ` if `mᵢ ≤ nᵢ` and `1` otherwise. -/
```
or am I missing something?

The exponent is `0`, for example `factorization_lcm_left 4 3 = 3`: writing `4 = 2 ^ 2 * 3 ^ 0` and `3 = 2^0 * 3 ^ 1`, then `factorization_lcm_left = 2 ^ 2 * 3 ^ 0`. In practice `factorization_lcm_left` only has the primes such the exponent in `a` is greater or equal to the exponent in `b` (with the same exponent as `a`). `factorization_lcm_right` does the opposite (with the difference that it keeps the primes that have strictly bigger exponent in `b`).

The point is that in our use of [Finsupp.prod](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/BigOperators/Finsupp.html#Finsupp.prod) we use the `Nat.factorization` only in the `if` condition, in the result we give the value by hand.

```suggestion
def factorizationLCMLeft (a b : ℕ) : ℕ :=
  (Nat.lcm a b).factorization.prod fun p n ↦
    if b.factorization p ≤ a.factorization p then p ^ n else 1
```

```suggestion
    ∃ z : G, orderOf z = Nat.lcm (orderOf x) (orderOf y) := by
```

```suggestion
  any_goals simp only [coprime_one_right_eq_true, coprime_one_left_eq_true] 
```
avoids the weird goal management below by killing all goals but one at once.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion any_goals simp only [coprime_one_right_eq_true, coprime_one_left_eq_true] ```
This is not so important, but maybe call if factorizationLCLLeft_dvd_left
… and ..._right

You could add a comment about what happens when `a=0` or `b=0`.
(If `a=0`, it is `1`; if `a>0` but `b=0`, it is `a`.)
Are you sure? `factorizationLCMLeft 4 0 = 1`  and `factorizationLCMLeft 4 0 = 1` (`#eval` works, so it is easy to check this equalities).
If I'm wrong (I made the computation in my head), then it is even more important to add a comment — and why not prove the thing, you more or less use it later on in the proofs, I think.

If `b = 0`, all of its exponents are `0`, so you get the same thing as the exponents of `a`, which is `a` if `a>0`, and `1` otherwise.
If `a = 0`, then all `k_i` are `0`, so you get 1.
In other words, for `(0,b)`it gives `1`, and for `(a,0)` with `a>0`, it gives `a`.
Seeing what you copied, you may have used `factorizationLCMRight`.
The product is over the divisors of `lcm a b`, so if one of `a` or `b` is `0` then the result is `1` (I've added the results).
I would add the fact that this element belongs to the submonoid generated by `x` and `y`.
Good idea.

nodes.body:
I think @alreadydone is the best way of handling this, using `orderOf_pow_orderOf_div` the proof becomes very reasonable.

I have to stop now, but thanks all for the suggestions!

Isn't `factorization_lcm_right a b` just `factorization_lcm_left b a`? If so, I'm not sure it's worth having the two functions -- and half the lemmas can go, as they are straightforward consequences of the symmetric version.

> Isn't `factorization_lcm_right a b` just `factorization_lcm_left b a`?

I don't think so: there is a difference when the same power of `p` divides both `a` and `b` exactly, in which case it shows up in only one of them (otherwise you could not get two coprime factors whose product is the lcm).

> Isn't `factorization_lcm_right a b` just `factorization_lcm_left b a`? If so, I'm not sure it's worth having the two functions -- and half the lemmas can go, as they are straightforward consequences of the symmetric version.

Almost, but not really: `factorization_lcm_left 2 2 = 2`, but `factorization_lcm_right 2 2 = 1`. The only difference is for prime that appears with the same exponent, we put them in `factorization_lcm_left 2 2` (this is arbitrary of course, but they have to go somewhere).
You're right, sorry. Maybe add a comment about that in one of the definitions?

Thanks!
